title: Surge Pricing Will Kill Us All

last_post.content:
I was hoping that this "unlearning #economics video would bring up the issue we have in NYC. Oh yes, you can raise prices, bring more drivers to the road. But, the road can only fit so many cars. After a point each additional car makes everyone move more slowly.

I live near Yankee Stadium. After game we go to the roof and watch the black cars play "slider puzzle" every inch of road is full. Nothing can move.

You get home faster on the subway.

#uber #surgpricing

I really like vaguely cute sounding optimistic cheery techno

title: Songs that use Chromatic Mediant chords

last_post.content:
I'm not good enough to figure this out myself. I learned it from Dave Bennett's excellent video on chromatic mediants, which is full of examples:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2_8D1F-wIqI

But what's a chromatic mediant? 🤔

'Mediant' just means 'third'. In a chromatic mediant we have two chords, ideally both major triads or both minor triads, that differ by a third and share a note. But what makes it 'chromatic' is that one of these triads is not in the same scale!

(2/n)

title: Tyler Morgan-Wall - Building an Entire City in R: Interactive 3D Data Visualization with Rayrender

last_post.content:
My talk from the @rstatsdc conference was just posted! Watch and learn how to build an entire 3D city in #RStats, using #rayshader and #rayrender. Also see how I used R to re-create a Washington Post dataviz in only a few lines of code, and how to turn your #Dataviz into an animated death star trench run!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8NV5MxcaWR4

We caught up with Richard moulds, the GM of Amazon BraKet - probably the most unusual service in AWS. It's a fully-managed service with APIs for accessing real, live, quantum computers living in cryogenic labs all around the world. https://youtu.be/gFo32NqxorM

What gives Depeche Mode's song Enjoy the Silence that creepy feel?

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_G0G1OjM5h0

I just learned one reason: a 'harmonic mediant'. Check out the part at 0:28 where Dave Gahan sings

Words like violence
Break the silence

The first line uses the notes 1 3♭ 5, which form a minor triad. The second uses 3♭ 5♭ 7♭, another minor triad. But while the first chord uses only notes in the minor scale, the second uses one note, 5♭, which is not in that scale!

Creepy!

(1/n)

Tomorrow!
https://youtu.be/gNF4YLPtgfA

The #reMarkable is out, I think, because it converts ePub to PDF and annotations are then layered on the PDF page. Changing ePub font size or page layout in turn would break the annotations's anchor points.
https://www.reddit.com/r/RemarkableTablet/comments/uz7ti3/comment/ia8zen2/?context=3

AFAIK the #SuperNote and #Boox do a better job at this.

"Time Is On My Side" turns 60 this year.

title: Relative velocity | Demonstration of constant speed with a moving trampoline

last_post.content:
A nice empirical demonstration of Galileo's principle of relativity: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GIMNS0YiHzY

If one replaces the person on the trampoline with a light beam bouncing up and down between two horizontal mirrors, and assumes that the speed of light is \(c\) in every inertial frame, one obtains (from Pythagoras) the well-known 'light clock" thought experiment of Einstein that derives the fact that such clocks slow down by a factor of √(1−𝑣²/𝑐²) when moving at a velocity \(v\).

The Shadoks.

These strange creatures invaded our televisions in 1968 and were rampant for most of the seventies in 🇫🇷. The opening of the first episod is a cosmographic treatise of the preposterous Shadokean universe!

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Les_Shadoks
Full video: https://youtu.be/tpD0Pdr7oD0

title: How In-Ear Monitors are Making Better Musicians

last_post.content:
Why do orchestras need conductors?

There are various reasons, of course, but here at 0:26 Adam Neely suggests one I hadn't thought about:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mHoljbkyAEs

The speed of light is faster than the speed of sound!

For a large orchestra it can take 0.1 seconds for sound to make a round trip between two performers... and that's a huge amount of time in music. So, get them synched up using light signals instead!

title: A. Vivaldi: Concerti con molti strumenti [Europa Galante - F. Biondi]

last_post.content:
How would the world be different if Bach's Brandenburg Concerti were lost... or had become popular much earlier?

They were not an unprecedented bolt out of blue. Compare the Concerti con molti strumenti, by Vivaldi:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZgE_x1-kkqY

Similar in some ways! And probably no coincidence: Bach spent time transcribing the works of Vivaldi.

So if the Brandenburg Concerti were lost, maybe we'd spend more time listening to Vivaldi!

(4/n, n = 4)

title: J.S. Bach Brandenburg Concertos  1 - 6, Claudio Abbado

last_post.content:
Listening to the Brandenburg Concerti again, I realized they're a great example of the importance of luck.

Bach dedicated them to Christian Ludwig, Margrave of Brandenburg-Schwedt, hoping to get a job. But Ludwig didn't have enough musicians to play them. Bach didn't get the job. The score was left unused in the Margrave's library until his death.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hbQORqkStpk

(1/n)

title: We need to talk about Dropout

last_post.content:
New video premieres in 15 minutes: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zu0hyIwKDmE

"We need to talk about Dropout", in which we talk about media, pivoting to video, the life and death of CollegeHumor, and discuss the Dropout video player.

As promised, on this last day of the year, I am writing the summary of the year 2022 and what it meant for GRASP.

First off, #GRASP is a #Lisp (s-expression) editor designed with mobile devices/tactile interfaces in mind. Here's what using it on a mobile device is supposed to look&feel like:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=H0YNZCO7gyQ

The above is a video recoreded with the old prototype (the one that I have presented during 2021 Scheme Workshop).

However, with the beginning of the year 2022, after some experimentation, I decided to rewrite the whole program from scratch.

The reasons for that were the following:
- the old prototype was written in Java (becasue, when I started, it was the only option I knew about for writing Android apps on an Android device), so that I would not be able to use GRASP to edit its own source code

- after I integrated GRASP with Kawa Scheme, I learned enough about Java, Android and Kawa to attempt rewriting the editor in Kawa Scheme

- after integration with Kawa Scheme the build times of the APK file increased significantly, so I needed a way for testing pieces of the application without rebuilding the whole thing

- the representation chosen in that prototype was fairly ad-hoc, and it would be difficult to modify it to represent dotted lists

- I wanted to be able to work on (and in) the app not only on my phone, but also on a conventional computer with a keyboard and a mouse

- I felt that adding certain features (like undo or keyboard editing) was hard in the existing code base

- I'm neither experienced nor passionate about Java (actually GRASP was my first and last program written in Java), whereas I am both passionate and experienced when it comes to writing Scheme

The point regading being able to test the application without rebuilding it, and about being able to write both on the mobile and conventional computers, has lead me to some interesting by-products.

First - for the purpose of testing - I created a backend which spits out GRASP rendering as ASCII art, which lets me write unit tests in the following way:

https://github.com/panicz/grasp-android/blob/master/stages/retreat/GRASP/src/test-painter.scm#L252

Second - I also built a terminal version of GRASP, so that I have a piece of code that I can quite literally run both on a computer and on the phone (via Termux,
which is my development environment). Dragging expressions in a terminal using a mouse feels insane!

title: December 6 - Zoe Cullen, Harvard Business School

last_post.content: Next was a fascinating talk by Zoë Cullen on the effects of #salary benchmarking at the #MIT Initiative on the Digital #Economy. The empirical results presented here demonstrates a significant compression of #wages to the mean when benchmarks are introduced, but there are some gains in average salary for low-skill positions overall. Highly recommend https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tzo6f7oYP1Y (4/5) #economics #labor #PeopleAnalytics

title: Session 4 - Overcoming the challenges of data sharing

last_post.content: Next was a nice panel on the challenges of #data sharing at the #AlanTuringInstitute with Tim Watson, Fernando Lucini, Cynthia Dwork, Rachel Dugdale, and Zoe Kourtzi. Personal data sharing with any organization is fraught with ethical concerns, and even techniques like #DifferentialPrivacy can cause more problems than they solve. Lots of these topics are discussed here https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=17lYBh4dV3o (3/5)

title: The Alan Turing Institute - Habitual Ethics

last_post.content: First was an excellent talk and discussion on Sylvie Delacroix's new book on habitual #ethics, with @lawrennd, Emran Mian, and David Leslie at the #AlanTuringInstitute. Lots to unpack from this tremendous conversation, and I liked the idea brought up that mirrored @msbernst's recent work on jury learning systems. Highly recommend https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OHweOGW5Ju4 (2/5) #AI #AIEthics

RT @privacylawyer@twitter.com

🐦🔗: https://twitter.com/privacylawyer/status/1608909543022661633

I never get excited for my birthday, but I do get pretty psyched for my blog birthday. Happy 13th, KrebsOnSecurity.com! (edited: I'm so old I forgot which birthday!)

I took the occasion of today's obligatory bday post to highlight some of the more notable cybercrime stories in 2022.

A big thank you to everyone here who has supported my work over the years!

https://krebsonsecurity.com/2022/12/happy-12th-birthday-krebsonsecurity/

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jRfuqpY-088

https://youtu.be/U12VPKJciZw

See my 10 parsecs resources page: https://gruze.org/10pc/resources/

title: Session 2 - Regulation in the age of AI

last_post.content: Last was a good panel on regulating #AI with Florian Ostmann, Julia Black, Nick Swanson, and Cosmina Dorobantu at the #TuringInstitute. The importance of international cooperation, modeling risks, and other topics and discussed in detail here https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mgzlrIvFLO8 (12/12)

title: Session 4, Public Policy Stage - Online Harms Observatory

last_post.content: Next was an introduction of the Turing Institute's Online Harms Observatory with Bertie Vidgen, Angus Williams, and Hannah Rose Kirk. I'm not sure how well this initiative will do post-Twitter, but still interesting to learn about https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gLLJjh7Y0P0 (11/12)

title: Session 4 - Foundation models: the new kid on the block?

last_post.content: Next was a nice discussion on #LLMs at the #TuringInstitute with Michael Wooldridge, Phil Blunsom, Peter Flach, and Angeliki Lazaridou. No uncritical optimism here, and overall a good overview of the space https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-Jlzcl7HKMI (10/12)

title: Allen School Colloquium: Natasha Jaques (Google + UC Berkeley)

last_post.content: Next was an amazing talk by Natasha Jaques on social #ReinforcementLearning and other topics. Coordinating multiple agents is extremely challenging, and getting to robustness around these models is even harder. Also it looks like she got the job! Highly recommend https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oUIsXQsfP-A (9/12) #AI #ML #RL

title: May 5 - Kristina McElheran, University of Toronto, Scarborough and Rotman

last_post.content: Next was a great talk by Kristina McElheran on using large scale #economic #data to assess the impact of predictive #analytics on business #performance at #MIT IDE. With unique data McElheran examines questions around what factors lead companies to gain benefit from these technologies and how large that benefit is. Highly recommend https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zq7jwUSLQyg (8/12)

Next was a fascinating talk by Gordon Burtch on the impact of owner social identity signaling on #retailer demand at the #MIT Initiative on the Digital #Economy. The interesting effects of Black and women owned business labels on #Yelp are unpacked here, also incorporating real visit #data to gain further insight into patterns. Highly recommend https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pMOjvAEpHqk (7/12)

title: Active human-machine interactions necessary for interpretability -  Isaac Kohane, Harvard University

last_post.content: Next was an important talk from Isaac Kohane on why active human interactions are needed for #AI interpretability at the #AlanTuringInstitute. Kohane goes into great detail about how current statistical models can spectacularly fail and the implications for use and design. Highly recommend https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UBSxftxjZPc (6/12)

title: Panel discussion, chaired by Hannah Fry - Interpretability, Safety and Security in AI

last_post.content: Next was a spicy panel discussion on the importance of #AI interpretability and the tradeoffs of #automation with Hannah Fry, Isaac Kohane, Aleksander Madry, Cynthia Rudin, and Manuela Veloso at the #AlanTuringInstitute. I can't say I agree with all the points brought up here, but it's an excellent, vigorous debate. Highly recommend https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=T8Q-vNAt1cc (5/12)

title: Computational Antitrust in Blockchain Ecosystems (McCaskill, Goanta, Greenwood, ten Seldam)

last_post.content: Next was an interesting conversation on computational #antitrust in #blockchain ecosystems with John McCaskill, @goanta, Dazza Greenwood, and Björn ten Seldam also at #CodeX. The public nature of blockchain transactions does allow for some interesting modeling opportunities which are explored here https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jb25Ikh0Ckc (4/12)

title: What To Research in Computational Antitrust

last_post.content: Next was an excellent panel on important research topics in computational antitrust (there are a lot!) with Thibault Schrepel, Teodora Groza, Björn ten Seldam, Aleksandra Wierzbicka, Kirill Ryabtsev, Thaiane Abreu, and Alexandru Șotropa at #StanfordCodex's Computational #Antitrust conference. It's almost impossible to succinctly summarize the variety of topics covered, highly recommend https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VNbFYOnOaTE (3/12)

First was an intriguing couple of sessions on algorithmic disgorgement and sunsetting robots at the #TechPolicyLab. Figuring out how to regulate #models built on ill-gotten #data and the destruction of pieces of #technology that people can form emotional bonds with are important problems and the rich discussion here examines both from multiple angles. Highly recommend https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vTcFtezZ2Ao (2/12) #AI #robotics #ethics #AIEthics
I made a video about my AwesomeWM config and some of my workflow with it: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3nseth86JLA

Here's one of my #projects: an audio player (written in #python) for playing music before live events that have a definite start time. It will play the tracks such that they end at the given time, making for a smooth start to the event.

Here's a short demo: https://youtu.be/sWdraAQPzFI
